dt: {bc}an example of a product that is not yet ready to be sold
{bc}a recording intended to show off a song or performer to a record producer

shortdef: an example of a product that is not yet ready to be sold

dt: {bc}to give a {d_link|demonstration|demonstration} of (something, such as a product or procedure) {bc}to show how (something) works, is prepared, or is done

dt.t: The chef {wi}demoed{/wi} everything. His first demo was peeling a carrot.
One dealer didn't even have demonstration software; the only thing he could {wi}demo{/wi} was the power light.

dt: {bc}to create a demo {dx_def}see {dxt|demo:1||2b}{/dx_def} recording of (a piece of music)

dt.t: … spent three months rehearsing and {wi}demoing{/wi} songs for their third album …

dt: {bc}to use (something, such as a product) in order to test its quality or value {bc}to try out (something)

dt.t: The surest way to pick exactly the right ski for your needs is to first narrow your choices to a workable number … and then go out and {wi}demo{/wi} three or four pairs to make your final selection.

shortdef: to give a demonstration of (something, such as a product or procedure) : to show how (something) works, is prepared, or is done
to create a demo recording of (a piece of music)
to use (something, such as a product) in order to test its quality or value : to try out (something)

dt.t: Brick salvaged from a {wi}demoed{/wi} fireplace and backyard path make up the new stoop and walkway.
My mom put little masks on me and my brother, gave us goggles and crowbars, and we {wi}demo'd{/wi} the walls.

et: combining form from Greek {it}dêmos{/it} "district, country, people, common people, political district in Attica," of uncertain origin

Greek {it}dêmos{/it} has traditionally been linked with Old Irish {it}dám{/it} "guests, company, retinue," Old Welsh {it}dauu,{/it} glossing Latin {it}cliens{/it} (hence, presumably, "member of a retinue"), Modern Welsh {it}daw, dawf{/it} "son-in-law." However, the semantic discrepancy between the two etyma is significant, and Celtic {it}*dāmo-/*dāmā-{/it} has more recently been explained as going back to {it}*dōmo-,{/it} a lengthened-grade adjectival derivative of Indo-European {it}*dom-o-s,{/it} "house, household." The further traditional link with Indo-European {it}*deh{inf}2{/inf}-{/it} "cut, divide" (whence Greek {it}daíomai, daíesthai{/it} "to divide"; cf. {et_link|tide:1|tide:1}), assuming a noun {it}*deh{inf}2{/inf}-mos{/it} meaning originally "part, division," is still possible, though it would be deprived of any support beside Greek.
